<s>the first sort, are extended over the whole length & breadth of 
the glass slips, whatever their dimensions may be, & are 
visible with weak candle or lamp light, but cannot be seen 
in day light. 
Binaries may be subdivided into six species. 
1st. Those formed without pressure, between two parallel 
contiguous surfaces, when only two pieces of glass are employed; 
not more than one set, & sometimes only part of a set of 
these have yet been perceived at once by this arrangement. 
2d Those formed between parallel surfaces when three 
pieces of glass are laid together; part of the two lower surfaces being in contact so as to form primaries between them, while 
the upper slip is pressed by its own weight alone. one, two, 
three, & even four setts of narrow fringes have been seen 
at once by this arrangement. 
3d Those formed when three pieces of glass are laid together, 
& pressed by their own weight alone; no more than one 
set has been seen at once by this arrangement; they are 
much broader & more irregular in shape than the second 
species; & altho the presence of the upper piece of glass 
is absolutely necessary for their production, they are always 
formed between the two lower contiguous surfaces. 
4th Those formed as diagonals in the Angle between two 
sets of the first species of primaries; these are always 
projected through the intersections of two sets of primaries 
with each other, & therfore have been denominated 
intersectionaries. 
5th. Irregular spectra, formed without pressure bet-
ween two plane glasses laid horizontally on a Table & 
viewed through two similar pieces of glass (slightly cem-
ented together to prevent shifting) & held in the hand at 
different angles of obliquity. These spectra are 
visible altho the double slip held in the hand is in some places 
eight or ten inches from those on the table; & when 
the double slip in the hand corrected from an angle 
of 45 <s>[text?]<\s> to an angle of 15 degrees, a new spectrum 
different from the former is seen in the reflected image 
of the object which cannot be seen in the object itself. <\s>
